"Spokane-Kalispel-Flathead has three major divisions, often referred to as if they were individual languages, although the differences are largely based on the degree of truncation of words and a difference between "r" in Spokane and "l" in Kalispel and Flathead" (pg. 5).

child.pub-comments: Possibly 500 speakers remaining (pg. 67). "Colville-Okanagan has several dialect divisions, although the lack of a systematic study makes it difficult to identify how many significant ones there are" (pg. 5). "The designation 'Nsilxcín' is used by members of the Colville community, south of the US-Canada border. Some members of the communities north of the border also use this term (although Mattina (personal communication) mentions that stress sometimes appears on the first syllable as in nsíylxcən). The collocation "ta nuknaqínxcən" 'in the language ofthe Okanagans' is also used north of the border" (pg. 68).

child.publications: Czaykowska-Higgins, Ewa & M. Dale Kinkade (eds.). 1998. Salish Languages and Linguistics: Theoretical and Descriptive Perspectives. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

child.pub-comments: 500 speakers (pg. 64). "Halkomelem is generally dived into at least three major dialects…although each of these consists of recognizable subdivisions" (pg. 4). "The indigenous designations for each of the three dialects of Halkomelem differ in ways that distinguish the dialects from each other (primarily in the alternation between l's and n's). We have chosen not to use an indigenous designation for the term 'Halkomelem' here so as not to privilege onedialec over the others. Not that in the indegenous designation for the Island dialect, 'q̲' is [q']" (pg. 68).

child.pub-comments: No major dialects (pg. 65). "There appears to be no indigenous designation for the dialect group represented by the term 'Northern Straits'. The name given here for the Semiahmoo dialect in fact refers to the name of the Semiahmoo community rather than the langauge itself. In the literature on Salish languages and in this book, the term 'Straits' is sometimes used interchangeably with the term 'Northern Straits'. In some earlier work on Salish, 'Straits' included both Klallam and Northern Straits" (pg. 68).

child.pub-comments: Fewer than 400 speakers (pg. 64).

"Linguists consider that Comox has an Island dialect and a Mainland dialect. Contemporary speakers of Sliammon (ʔayʔaǰúɵəm), however, consider themselves to be distinct from the Island people, and within their communities discussions about the appropriate designation for the language are ongoing (Susan Blake, personal communication). There is, however, no indigenous designation that groups the two dialects together" (pg. 67)

child.publications: Czaykowska-Higgins, Ewa & M. Dale Kinkade (eds.). 1998. Salish Languages and Linguistics: Theoretical and Descriptive Perspectives. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.
child.pub-comments: No major dialects.

child.publications: Czaykowska-Higgins, Ewa & M. Dale Kinkade (eds.). 1998. Salish Languages and Linguistics: Theoretical and Descriptive Perspectives. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.
child.pub-comments: Around 20 speakers, no major dialects (pg. 64). "In the orthography used by the community, 'k,x' are [q,x], '7' is [ʔ], and 'sh' is [š]. In speaker of the language, the collocation ta Sk̲wx̲wú7mesh snichimchet 'our Squamish language' is used (Jacobs 1992)" (pg. 68).
